## Meetings & Reports

**Weekly Meeting Reports:** These reports keep me and your peers informed about your work.
- Share what youâ€™ve been working on, roadblocks that you need help with, and whatâ€™s next.

- No need to report everything (e.g., TA duties).

- This is *not* about proving productivity.

- Keep it *brief, clear, and focused on interesting updates*.

- You may receive useful feedback from others.

**Weekly One-on-One Meetings [Duration: 30 minutes]:**
The goal is to *get feedback*. Come prepared. We will walk through your weekly meeting report so make sure it is filled atleast a day before the meeting:

- Briefly summarize what you worked on and key challenges.

- Focus the discussion on items where you want feedback.

- When discussing challenges, bring *possible options or approaches*.

- Any topic is welcomeâ€”*technical or personal*.


**Weekly Group Meetings [Duration: 60 minutes]:**
Typically feature a paper presentation (your own or one youâ€™ve read). Announce ahead of time in the team channel. *Go over the paper you wan to present* and highlight their limitations, and future work that you can think of. Spend a few hours on the day before to prepare a short presentation using the template covering the following slides: (a) Introduction/Background; (b) Problem Statement, (c) Experimental Setup; (d) Results and Analysis; and (e) Limitations and Future Work that you can work on as new projects.
See the section on how to make presentations.
The goal here is to get you learn *how to make presentations and practice giving talks*. For me and others, this will give us a chance to identify interesting extensions to work on as projects.

**Weekly Project Meetings [Duration: 60 minutes]:**
Each project has a **weekly meeting** with its members to discuss progress and updates, roadblocks and how to address them, and how to position the work.


**Brainstorming Sessions [Duration: TBD as needed]:**
Held as needed to:
- Review papers and identify research problems to work on.

- Build research themes (e.g., for grants or theses).

- Expose you to the *grant-writing and ideation process*.

- Involve one or more students who may later work on resulting projects.

- Once ideas are finalized, new projects will be added to the research project list.

## Policies for Vacation

I encourage students to take time off to recharge and can help return to problems with a fresh perspective. If you plan to take a vacation, please ensure the following:

- Confirm there are no critical deadlines during this period (e.g., submissions, rebuttals).

- Planning ahead ensures minimal disruption, inform Vasisht and obtain approval.

- Notify your collaborators and ensure your absence does not disrupt shared projects.

- Cancel all one-on-one meetings with Vasisht for the duration.

- Coordinate with project collaborators to decide whether project meetings should also be paused.
